title: Will "implementation day" for the Iranian nuclear deal occur before Iran's legislative elections?
preds: In light of sanctions being lifted, yes.

(CNN)Iran has completed the necessary steps in a deal to restrict its nuclear program, meaning international economic sanctions are lifted, officials from the EU and the U.N. nuclear watchdog agency said Saturday.

With the release of the reporters held hostage I see the Gov't moving through all the "hard" decisions prior to the elections to seem more moderate...

Based on comments from all sides it looks like it will go ahead. I have it lower than my prefered 98% because of the potential snafu with the detaining of US sailors. As per melancholy-aeon's comment, are hardliners trying to delay if not derail this deal?

Maybe not such a sure thing now. We'll see if it lasts more than a day. (h/t @jeremylichtman)

Reuters has reported that the work to be completed at the Arak nuclear reactor is still ongoing http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-arak-idUSKCN0UQ19G20160112 ; http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-araq-idUSKCN0UP1Y120160111 .  However it does point to dynamics within the region along with the oversupply of oil in the global economy could potentially derail completion of the JCPOA requirements for declaration of implementation day in the nuclear deal.  The deepening of the sectarian divide among Sunnis and Shi'ites and its affect on proxy conflicts within the region could potentially affect the progress of implementation day requirements.   Iran has however indicated that does not intend to allow these factors to influence its ability to complete JCPOA requirements prior to the Februaryelection.  Reformists and conservatives in the Iranian theocratic political system have much to gain and provide considerable influence on the electoral outcomes.

Dateline 1-12-16 Iran reported that it had removed the core (NYT) of its plutonium-producing nuclear reactor as part of its obligations under the deal reached between Iran and international powers in July. Disabling the reactor is required by the nuclear agreement before international sanctions can be lifted. Daily Brief: Council on Foreign Relations [dailybrief@e.cfr.org]

The fresh Saudi-Iranian beef forces US to pick a side, which would almost definitely be the Saudis'.  http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/d98ce7f6-b94c-11e5-b151-8e15c9a029fb.html.  Forecast adjusted lower.

Those of you who follow much more closely than I do, does this throw a wrench in timetable---if true or even vague? This is from Stratfor. I honestly don't know but have been skeptical of this rapid timetable iran has been on.  Maybe I am paranoid.  :)

Predictions of an imminent end to sanctions were echoed by European Union foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini, who said Monday in Prague that the implementation day of the Iran agreement “could come rather soon.” Last week, Secretary of State John F. Kerry said it was just “days away.”

Upped my forecast on the contradicting reports on the Arak reactor. Either way it seems that notwithstanding everything progress continues and we are heading towards implementation day.

The Obama administration, Kerry said, is “prepared to move on that day” on the nuclear-related sanctions on Iranian oil, banking and commerce that it promised to end as part of the July agreement

Keeping same percentage. There are still a number of items for Iran to accomplish. IAEA has to verify the uranium quantities remaining, the Fordham nuclear reactor has to be plugged, and agreed-to IAEA personnel and electronic monitoring of  sites has to be put into place.
substantial compliance announced today will bring implemenation day before majlis election.
Iran reportedly shipped enough material to Russia and technically complied with IAEC that Implementation day probably in next 30-60 days. As of today there is substantial compliance.

(no change) Would go higher except for worries about the Supreme Leader and the IRGC.

Dateline 12-29-15 Iran delivered almost all of its stockpile of low-enriched uranium to a Russian ship, fulfilling a major step (NYT) in the nuclear deal struck last summer. The shipment contained roughly 25,000 pounds of nuclear material that experts say would leave Iran without enough fuel to manufacture a nuclear weapon. U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry called the move (BBC) “one of the most significant steps Iran has taken toward fulfilling its commitment.” U.S. officials say implementation of the nuclear deal, in which the United States would unfreeze some $100 billion in assets, could be weeks away. Daily Brief: Iran Delivers Enriched Uranium to Russia; Council on Foreign Relations [dailybrief@e.cfr.org]

Iran targeting Jan 15, leaves 6 weeks for IAEA verification before Feb 26.  So far Iran has been going fast, and target date fits with estimates of how long Arak calandria work will take (2-3 weeks).  IAEA will take a few weeks, but this schedule may leave enough time.
Closing of IAEA file on Iranian weapons research indicates another positive step towards implementation day. For this (as much a positive statement from IAEA as a regulatory one) I'll add another 5%

http://tass.ru/en/world/844436
"Iranian specialists will complete works on dismantling the core of the heavy water reactor in Arak in two-three weeks, Russia’s permanent representative at international organizations in Vienna Vladimir Voronkov told journalists on Wednesday.
"Iranians say this work can be completed in 2-3 weeks," Voronkov said. "They say it is attainable in the rather short timeframe," he added.
The diplomat noted that Iran is working on reactor core dismantling together with China and the United States. "Formal organizational and technical issues exist but from the point of view of implementation everything is proceeding in the routine mode," Voronkov stressed. "This issue will disappear from the agenda in 2-3 weeks," he said.
According to Russia’s Permanent Representative to International Organizations in Vienna Vladimir Voronkov,  Iran will send the surplus amount of enriched uranium to Russia already in the coming days.
"The logistics have been established through the port at Bushehr and it [enriched uranium] will be loaded and sent to Russia in coming days," the envoy said."
IAEA closed probe into nuclear weapons meaning they are on track

"According to Voronkov. all countries of the P5+1 group of international mediators, namely the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council and Germany, are ready to support a draft resolution of the board of governors of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) closing Iranâ€™s nuclear dossier.
He said the joint Iran-P5+1 commission was very much likely to finalize the draft resolution and distribute it among the council members by the end of the day.
"There is an understanding that it will be passed. No one is against, all want the implementation day to come the soonest possible," he said. "There are almost next to no differences, everything is likely to be smooth but there are things that are to be polished."
"The process is underway," Voronkov noted. "We hope the draft will be distributed among the members of the board of governors by the end of the day."
According to the Russian diplomat, Tehran, which demands ultimate closure of its nuclear dossier, will be satisfied with the resolution. "However I cannot be certain about the result, as the consultations are still underway," he said. "I hope its will be a successful story."

Inching up a bit based on the news and general optimism regarding the PMD report. Apparently there may be issues related to previous nuclear efforts, but they do not appear to present a hindrance to the implementation of the JPCOA.
Implementation day in the first week of January? Time to get rich! As for those bah, humbug hardliners – their glory days are fading.

1) First confirmation, I believe, by IAEA that PMD report will, indeed, be made available next week. (+1)
2) Iran has removed "quite a large number of centrifuges at quite a high pace" (+1)
3) The IAEA board may or may not "close" the PMD matter. That the board is required to do more than accept/reject the report, but is to use the report for a subsequent decision of closing/keeping open the PMD matter, is complete news to me, and indicates the PMD report may be more than a simple perfunctory activity. It is unclear what would happen if the IAEA board decided not to close the PMD matter. The JCPOA is not, to my understanding, contingent in any way upon the PMD board vote; yet the very open-endedness of a potential "keep the PMD dossier open" board vote adds uncertainty to the JCPOA outcome, since, apparently, from the perspective of Iran, it would provide an excuse for any party to renege upon the JCPOA. (-1)

I've decided that the Arak milestone may be less of a hurdle than I expected. Upping significantly and will probably go higher. Part of my rationale is accepting that any change to Arak may be deferred (with agreement by IAEA or P5+1) until after sanctions are removed. Thanks to all who offered the "plan" update.

Does anyone know if merely a "plan" to reconfigure Arak is enough of a milestone toward Implementation Day? Earlier I read/assumed it needed to be physically changed but now wonder.

Increasing based in the IAEA report shared by Institute for Science and International Security (the "good" ISIS - they had that name first).   Below is also a link in to the IAEA report.   It looks like IAEA believes the Iranians are complying with the requirements and predict the criteria (e.g. centrifuges) will be met by the end of December.   It appears there are two items that are still under review: Possible Military Dimensions -PMD is pending but suspect some way will be found to meet that requirement.   The other item is compliance with "additional protocol and "implementation of modified code 3.1."   This refers to transparency and access to sites for IAEA inspections.   On page 5, item 18 on the IAEA document there is a statement that says: 
 "On 18 October 2015, the Director General received a letter from the Permanent Representative of Iran to the Agency informing the Agency pursuant to paragraph 8 of Annex V of the JCPOA that, effective on JCPOA Implementation Day,29,30 Iran will provisionally apply the Additional Protocol to
its Safeguards Agreement, pending its ratification by the Majlis (Parliament), and will fully implement the modified Code 3.1 of the Subsidiary Arrangements to its Safeguards Agreement.31."
Since on implementation day sanctions will be removed, this may result in sanction removal prior to Iranian Parliament approval and therefore implementation of the transparency/ inspection component.   Did not increase my forecast above 75% because this could cause a delay.
ISIS REPORT:  http://isis-online.org/uploads/isis-reports/documents/ISIS_Analysis_IAEA_Report_November_18_2015_Final.pdf
IAEA REPORT: http://isis-online.org/uploads/isis-reports/documents/gov-2015-65.pdf
ARTICLE ABOUT CODE 3.1 & IRAN's historyhttp://southasianvoices.org/irans-tryst-with-the-modified-code-3-1/

Some aspects of the IAEA report seem positive - IR-1 centrifuges being disassembled and put under IAEA verification more rapidly than expected for instance.
The rate of disassembly of IR-2m centrifuges so far has been 6/day on average (much slower than IR-1) - either taking more care or started later - or work stoppage? - but have 848 remaining at Natanz.  Sounds like progress might be slower at Fordow?
I'm increasing my forecast based on the latest news that Iran has been making progress. But, I still think there is alot of  work to go, and a headwind. I  will be waiting for the Dec. 2  report.

Updating and increasing likelihood of implementation day before the elections.    No major change in my logic from Nov 11.   I don't believe IAEA will want to jeopardize the agreement, so will compromise somehow if needed, even if actual deadlines aren't met.    Khamenei has said little more about the plan and rather is blaming U.S. and west for ISIS creation and seems to be working on new environmental issues so basically onto other, distracting activities for now. PRO implementation date before February:  
- Iran desperate to have sanctions removed for financial reasons
- Rafsanjani recently provided information on Iran's previous nuclear ambitions.   Until then those had been consistently denied. Iran's stated primary goal by both hardliners and moderates has been to remove the sanctions. The Imam Ayatollah Seyyed Ali Khamenei has been quoted saying, “Our negotiators are trying to take the weapon of sanctions away from the enemy” which was cited on the Iranian website ALALAM at http://en.alalam.ir/.  Iran will make full effort to meet the  12 compliance issues by end of 2015 and by latest January 2016. It will then be up to IAEA to verify compliance, the  U.S. President and Congress to remove sanctions.
The weeks after elections offer a good opportunity to move ahead with meeting the remaining requirements with less electoral rethoric creating internal tensions.
Iran will start to see how much upside there is in cooperation

There is a strong incentive to control the timing of the lifting of sanctions so that the Iranian oil re-entering the market corresponds with any rebound in the energy prices. This helps the U.S. and most of Europe keep inflation low in light of an overdue global recession with the added benefit of keeping the pressure on Putin and putting him into direct competition with Iran for the same markets.

The central key to implementation day is the submission of AIEA reports verifying the requirements for the lifting of sanctions and other requirements.  Settling the requirements for the PMD issue is a necessary but not a sufficient condition for the meeting deadlines by this date.  Even if Iran met all requirements on their end prior to implementation day this is not sufficient.  Verification, deliberation and declaration of requirements having been met are important aspects of implementation.

Getting the implementation through before the elections will be critical from many points of view. 1. Rouhani will get a clearer mandate as he can show that he is progressive to get the support of the frustrated Iranian middle class that wants to see change happen and their lives to get better. 2. The more inclusive they are proven working with the international community the clearer the mandate to fight ISIS in Syria. Iranians may not appear to want to cooperate with USA but through back channel negotiations Russia, Iran, USA and Saudi each have varying digress of threat from ISIS. They would want to cut the head of the monster in the short term and deal with Syria in the long term. 3. The falling oil prices will hurt Iran's economy as it has done in Venezuela, Gulf and Russia. The faster the implementation is done the faster Iran can start planning its short term future.

Iran's current political leadership (Rouhani et al) is eager for implementation to occur before the elections, because going to the polls after clearing the way to lift sanctions will be a vote-winner for them. Conversely, this may be precisely why Iran's conservatives and security-minded establishment may not want implementation to occur that early.
